document.text: Yesterday was the 100th a n n i versary of the establishment of a U. iS. Post Office at what is bow Appo mattox, Virginia. Information secured from Nation al Archives and the Post Office De partment, Washington, D. C., tells an interesting story of a full cen tury of mail service here. There have been 20 postmaster andor acting postmaster ap pointments in the 100 years of operation and the incumbent, E. LeRoy Smith, has served longer than any other. The name of the office has been changed several times. On February 23, 1855, a fourth class post office was established here and was call ed Nebraska, Virginia. The first postmaster was Samuel D. McDear- mon. Salary amounted to 6.01. The office operated under the name of Nebraska, Virginia until September 21, 1894, when it was changed to Appomattox. However, due to confusion with the Old Ap pomattox Court House community, the ñamé of the post office here changed on January 15, 189 to West Appomattox, Virginia. It oper ated under that name until June 27, 1906, when it took the present name of Appomattox, Virginia. The office became third class in 1909 and second class in 1987. In mid-1955 it is scheduled to become first class, due to volume of busi ness. Several years ago it became first class, but reverted to second class due to a shift in parcel post business. The following is a list of post masters and their terms Samuel D. MeDearmon, February 23, 1855 Richard H, Mavin, December 31. 1855 Robert I, Boaz, October 4, 1866 Thomas E. Walton, December 22 1867k D- Hix, April 20, 1869 Willbfo l CoIKntf April 1 , i860 Mrs. Mary J. Atwood, February 10, 1666.  Ada A. Landrum, June 26, 1866 N. H. Gregory, October 30, 1867 Miss Elizftbéth H. Dee, Jániury 21, 188 Rufus Furdum, January 1, 1873 Samuel H. Coleman, July 26, 1889 John S. Plunkett, May 9, 1898 Robert Irby, May 7, 1897 Leslie F. Ferguson, May 20, 1918 Robert Irby, April 28, 1922 Lula G. Irby, Acting Postmaster. Ap ril 21, 921 Alfred R. Harwood, Acting Poet- master, May 15, 7931 Joseph E. Dinwiddle, June 1, 1982 E. LeRoy Smith, Acting Poet- master, June 1, 1034 Regular Appointment, March 8, 1936. However, this was not the first pqst. office in what is now Appomat tox County, Tie following inform ation  supplied by the National Archives and reports of the Post Office Department Appomattox County, Virginia The records show that this office was established on April 1, 1811, under the name of Floods, Buckings ham County, Virginia, with Thomas Trent the first postmaster. It is shown that the name oi the county was changed to Prince Edward on March 22, 1837, that the name of the office was changed to Clover Hill on July 7, 1837 and that the county in which the office was lo cated was changed to Appomattox sometime between September 23, 1845 and June 30, 1849. The re cords show that the name of the office was changed to Appomattox Court House on February 3, 1859 and changed to Appomattox on July 3, 1892.  It therefore appears that the his tory of a post office at what is now without a post office but known as Old Appomattox Court House, is equally interesting. That part of the county was in Buckingham when the post office was established as Floods in 1811. Later it became a part of Prince Edward and finally Appo mattox in 1845. Shortly after the burning of the court house in 1892, the court house was rebuilt at what is now the Town of Appomattox, and final ly the post office at the historic old village was discontinued. It was of ficially Appomattox Court House, Virginia, at the time Gen. Lee sur rendered to Gen. Grant. Undocumented stories often told here relate that in the gold rush days a hundred years and more ago?- some family started out for Ne braska, got this far and liked the place so much that they decided to settle here and call this Nebraska. This newspaper has no proof of that

document.text: William Pitzer Gills, who died at his home, Locust Grove, Friday morning, was the son of James Thomas and Cornelia Terri 1 Pitzer Gills. Though jiorn in Buckingham county, he moved to Appomattox in his boyhood on account of the death of his father. He then made his home with his uncle, the late Will iam Gills, who for many years was treasurer of the the county. He at tended the first public school evei taught in this county, Judge David A. Christian being the teacher. Mr. Gills engaged in various aeti- ties until the infirmities or age made, it necessary for him to retire from, public life. He was a senool trus.et of Appomattox county also serving as clerk to the school board, man carrier on R. F. D. No. 2, employed at one time by the Norfolk and Wes tern Railway, besides managing his arm near Appomattox. He was a iason and a Woodman of the  orld, and a Democr t who was un- werving in his par loyaly. Fii nany-lyears he was a faithful dea- on of Liberty Baptist church and teacher in the Sunday School. The deceased was a man whose lie was marked by fidelity to prin- ple. His was a goodly heritage of u ture and Godliness from an an cestry distinguished in the early history of America. Those who came in con4act with him were impressed by the deep spirituality of his nature. t  The funeral took place Sunday afternoon at Liberty Baptist church The Rev. H. Frederick Jones, the pastor, and the Rev. William May- field Thompson, a former pastor, conducting the services. The choir ,f the church sang Mr. Gills favor ite hymn, Rock of Ages. Tenny sons immortal poem, Crossing the Bar, was read and played on the pipe organ as a processional. Inter ment took place in the family plot in Liberty Cemetery, that part of the service. being conducted by the Masonic order. A host of friends and acquaintances, with many beautifa floral tributes attested to the love and high regard in which Mr. Gills was held in Appomattox and through out the state. Ihe active pallbearers were A. T. Inge, C. S. McDeormon, R. L. j Burk?, A. R. Harwood, J. C David son, N R. Featherston, B. G. An derson, Luther J. Morris. Honorary pallbearers included R. B. document.text: week H. H. Caldwell, Jr. entered the lists for this office. Commonwealth Attorney It is presumed that the incumbent, G. F. Abbitt, Jr. will file and will be the only candidate. County Treasurer J. Garland Plunkett and Thomas T. Martin ape the announced candidates. David T. Robertson, the incum bent sheriff, was appointed to fill out the term of the late H. W. Mc Kinney, and four years ago won a full term. He was opposed in that election four years ago by Vernell Mitchell. Sheriff Robertson inform ed The Times-Virginian this week that he would be a candidate, and to date no other has announced. The two-way race for Commission er of the Revenue will find H. H. Caldwell, Jr. opposing the veteran incumbent, J. H. OBrien. Mr. Cald- will be making his first bid for public office. He is the son of H. H. Caldwell, of Route 3, Appomattox. He graduated at Appomattox High School in 1943 and entered the Navy as Aviation Cadet August 10 of that year. While in the service he took special courses at the Universities of South Carolina and Georgia. He served on the USS. Bismarck Sea, and was on same when the carrier was sunk by a Jap dive bomber at tack Feb. 23, 1945. He was among the rescued survivors. He entered V. P. I. in the fall of 1945, and re ceived his B. S. degree in 1949. He was president of the civilian student foody his senior year. Since he has been employed with American To bacco Co., Schaffer Pen Co., and since 1954 with Gary Steel Products Corp, Lynchburg, as assistant to the general sales manager..

We kuow that he is so crusty and lagreeMble that no one would have him ai d so he thought he would make others dissatisfied. We are old-fashioned enough to be lieve that  what God has joined together let not man put mho oiler, and webelieve that such views .s Ar- voniu expresses are calculated to do harm. This lovely Indian summer weath er is all that one could wish aud the three big frosts of lust week seem to have put new life in some of us, and every one is hustling getting ready for winter, which will soon be here. Not two months till Christmas we can hardly realize it. Time just seems to have taken wings and flown away. 1he schools generally have open ed well, ami the teachers seem foil of eiiihusiaem for their winteis ork. Miss Bertha Woolridge te. ovts a good enrollment. Miss Sadie Coleman ep-nt Sun day at hume. She has a flue School, at Hurt8T!le. Her enrollment is 25 and most of them attend regn- irly. She expresses herself as charmed with tbe people and the neighborhood generally. Rev. Mr. Ellison pieaehed a good sermon at Forest last Sunday. Mr. and Mrs. T W. fi ler arid, Miss Madlaine Coleman visited rela tives near Reedy Springs on Satur day und Sunday. Mr. C. N- Alibi!V little fill, Elizabeth, is quite tick with pm u- monia. The hildrcu o. .Mr. I. O. Abbitt are il also. Mises Bessie and Elvu Col. man had a most enjoyable visit in in llnrtsville neighborhood last week. They visited at the charming home of Mr. Witt Coleman and attended a party given at Mr. Agees Friday night. They report a most delight - ful time, lots of pretty girls, good looking boys and elegant nin.de. There were men bers of five differ ent families of Colemans present. We are sorry to learn of the ser ious illness of little Hamoer, the bright little son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmond Cawthom, of Lynchburg, and trust that a merc.ful  Heavenly Father will spare him to his pa rents. Making molasses is now a thing of the past in this neighborhood,though molasses candy is still very much in evidence and the young folks ate still having sweet old times, es pecially one young man who fell in the skimming hole. We ure sorry to leain oi- the con tinued illness of Mrs. John Evans. Leslie Dixon, the little grandson of Mr. and Mrs. William Mann has been verv sick. We are glad to see Mr. John Plunkett out a ain after quite a bad spell of sickness.

document.text: W ELLS . CARTER Miss Mattie Virginia Carter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. T. R. Carter, Sr., of Appomattox, became the bride of Fred Neal Wells, of Knoxville, Tennessee, son of Mrs. Dorothy Wells and the late Mr. Wells at 800 P. M., Saturday, April 10, 1954, in the New Hope Baptist Church, Vera, Virginia, with the Rev. John P. Leitner, pastor, officiating. The church was decorated with ferns, gladioli and ivy, and lighted with candlehras. Music was render ed by Miss Rosa Mae Wooldridge, soloist Mrs. David Plunkett, violin ist, and Miss Easly Shuford, pianist. Given in marriage by her father, the bride wore a gown of Chantilly lace and satin. Her fingertip veil was caught to a sequin and pearl bandeau. She carried a Bible, with gardenias and stephanatosis. Mrs. Robert M. Morris was matron of honor. She wore a dress of pink taffeta, and carried a bouquet of purple dutch iris and pink roses. Bridesmaids were Mrs. William Rumble, of Phidelaphia, Pa., and Miss Shirley Duncan, of Pulaski. They wore blue and yellow taffeta dresses with net, and carried bou quets of yellow dutch iris and yel low roses. Lois Morris, niece of the bride, was flower girl. Jerry Wells, brother of the bride groom was best man. Groomsmen were David W. Carter and Robert M. Morris. A reception was given in the home of the brides sister. She was assisted in serving by Mrs. Richard Carter and Mrs. William D. OBrien. The bride is a graduate of the Vir ginia Baptist Hospital School of Nursing. After a wedding trip, the couple will make their home at Knox ville, Tennessee.

Naw, said Tobias  Strong, taking careful aim at a box of ashes already well saturat ed with a fertilizing solution of nico tine, whats a bull-fiddle? Its a contraption calculated to make you wish you were In the here after or hadnt left the heretofore, said MePeak. Wliats it fur? asked Tobias. Fox-drivers, boilings and tilings generally where a noise is wanted, said MePeak. Where! Lije git it? asked Tobias, squinting- his eye at the box of ashes for a more sure aim. Made It, said MePeak. Made it? queried I.ije. Yes, said MePeak, Lije can do anything from knitting a garter to sawing logs. Never saw but one thing In my life that Lije couldnt do if he set out to. Whats that interest. Get away from the Widow Parker. He tried it, lait couldnt make it, said MePeak, with a mournful shake of the head,  twns a great loss to the country when I.ije got married. Whercd he go to? asked Tobias. O, hes living over on Pleasant Ridge, but dont amount to nawthlug, responded MePeak. Sho, MePeak, remonstrated Deacon Plunkett, T.IJs all right. Belns youve r.e-.er married youve no right to judge In such matters. I.ijes settled down like a man orto when hes mar ried. O yes, hes settled down, admitted MePeak, sarcastically, lies settled so hard that ho never cracks a smile unless the linby cuts a tooth or some fool thing like that. Lije used to bo a great one, lie added regretfully, be fore the Widow Barker got hold of him. Ah, well, MePeak, everybody hes to be a fool sometime, drawled Tobias, still eyeing the ash-box. Wlints she got agin It? asked Tobias. O, wliats any woman got against anything? responded MePeak. es pecially widow women? document.text: UDC Holds Convention The 79th Annual Convention was held this year at the Hilton Inn in Virginia Beach, Virginia. Those attending from Appo m attox were Mrs. Lena I Eversole, president, Appomat tox Chapter, Mrs. Harriett Cunningham, first Vice-presi- I dent, Mrs. Cliff Plunkett, Virginia Division Registrar,  Mr. and Mrs. Calvin Roblnson, Miss Mamie Cultop and Mrs. Rachel Lawson. Memorials were given for all deceased members a t the Galilee Episcopal Church at Virginia Beach and a wreath I was made up of white I carnations on green easil and this wreath was taken to Norfolk and placed at the Confederate Monument there. Our own president made a lovely report on the activities that our chapter has taken part in this year. The banquet waa lovely the setting was Love - colors were - red and green. Mrs. Lawson was such a gracious hostess. She invited us to stay in her cottage and I must say it waa lovely. The ocean breeze, sun rise and sun set was so pretty. Wish I were an artist - with brush and easel The convention next year will be in Arlington, Virginia.

document.text: UDC DINNER MEETING The Appomattox Chapter of the United Daughters of the Confederacy met on Thurs., May 20 at6 p.m. at the home of Mrs. Helen Gunter. There were 17 members and one visitor in attendance. Pledges to the United States Flag and salutes of the Virginia Flag and the Confederate Flag were led by the president, Mrs. Lena Eversole. The ritual was read by Mrs. Mary Moore and the Confederate prayer by Mrs. Geneva Childers. An invitation has been extended to members to attend the Massing of the Flags in Richmond on Thurs., June 3. Members are planning to enter a float in the 4th Railroad Festival to be held Oct. 15 and 16. Mrs. Eversole appointed the following committee for this - Mrs. Noma Rae Moore, chairman and Mrs. Harriett Cunningham, Mrs. Lena Ever sole, Mrs. Mary Moore, Mrs. M argaret Lee, Mrs. Ruby Lewis, Mrs. Louise Plunkett and Mrs. Frances Harvey. Cards are being sent to our shut-ins. Mrs. Lucille Ferrell, histor ian, gave an interesting talk on William Ranson Pegram, a colonel during the Civil War, who is described by one of his officers as The Truest Christian, the most faithful and the most superb soldier in all the world. document.text: U D C Meeting The Appomattox Chapter of the United Daughters of the Confederacy met on Thursday, April 15, at 730 p.m. at Farmers National Bank, T ri-. angle Plaza Branch. There were 17 members ip attendance. Pledges to the United States Flag and salutes of the Virginia Flag and the Confederate Flag were led by toe president, Mrs. Lena Eversole. The ritual was read by Mrs. Frances Harvey. Also the Confederate Prayer by Mrs. Harvey. Mrs. Frances Harvey, secre tary, read the minutes of the last meeting which were approved. Mrs. Louise Plunkett gave a report on the memorial fund. Members voted. to donate 10.00 to the Skip Island Memorial Fund, ft  t Mrs. Eversole announced that the 3rd District Confer ence will meet on May 22 at 10 a.m. at the Parish House of the Trinity Episcopal Church, Main St., South Boston Va. Mrs. ucille Fertoll, histo Ian, gaVq an interesting talk on EdmundRuffins. Mrs. C. A. Moore led the group in singing southern songs, closing with Blest Be the Tie That Binds. Delicious refreshments were served by the hostesses Mrs. Wiley Moore,  Mrs. Alton Moore, Mrs. Claude A. Moore, Mrs. H. L. Wilkerson, Mrs. E. J. Hillsman and Mrs. B. Curray Harvey. The May meeting will meet on May 20 at 6 p.m. in the home of Mrs, Helen Gunter for a covered dish supper. Mrs. Tilden Lee, U.D.C Publicity

document.text: Two new directors were el ected Thursday, Jan. 20 at the annual members meeting of Co- operativeBuilding and Loan As sociation, Lynchburg. Members of the Appomattox Chapter, United Daughter of the Confederacy, meeting Thursday evening at Maudes for their annual dinner honoring Confed erate heroes Lee, Jackson and Maury, expressed disappoint ment that the scheduled speak er could not appear, but they were rewarded, otherwise, in the substitute speakers who presented historical papers and facts of interest. Mr. Jerry A. Burke, Appo mattox businessman and retired superintendent of Appomattox schools, found that he could not be present. Three chapter members volunteered to be a part of the evening  Mrs. Rachel F. Lawson, who read an account of Surrender at Appo mattox on April 9, 1865 M rs. Lucille Ferrell, who read an account concerning R . E. Lees mother and Mrs. Wiley Morris, who dipped even further back into history to read the will of General George Washingtons mother. Mrs. Clifford Plunkett, re gistrar for the Va. Division, was in charge of registration of members and guests for the ev ening affair. Mrs. Lawsons paper was a copy of a personal interview she held with Martha Mildred Ste vens Craig, an interview which was printed about 31 years ago. In the account Martha Mildred  Aunt Millie , told of her en counters with Union troops in the old village of Appomattox on April 9, 1865. She was nurse maid to Charles Sackett Peers at the time. Little Charles father, George Peers, was clerk of court. The faithful nursemaid hid herself and the child until the shooting ceased in the village.

document.text: Tuesday of this week, Sunset at Appomattox, a documentary film,, produced in Hollywood, had its pre miere before a blue ribbon list of dignataries in Lynchiburg. Nearly 200 saw the advance showing, and came away thrilled at the splendid reproduction of the events of April 9, 1865 at Appomattox. At a dinner at the Virginian Ho tel preceding the showing, Represen tative W. M. Abbitt was toastmaster. Fred Helsaibeck, vice-mayor of the City of Lynchburg, gave the invoca tion. Distinguished guests, including educators and historians, were intro duced. Major-General U. S. Grant, III, grandson of Ulyssis S. Grant, spoke briefly, praising the peace at Appomattox reuniting the na tion. Rev. Richard H. Lee, a kinsman of R. E. Lee, spoke in the same vein. William A. Hart, director of adver tising, E. I. DuPont Company, pro ducers of Sunset at Appomattox, told the story of how the film, was made. Conrad L. Wirth, Director, National Park Service, thanked the DuPont Company for this documen tary contribution. Sunset at Appomattox will be televised nationally on DuPonts Cavalcade of America program, over ABC network, Tuesday night, Oct. 20. We understand WLVA - TV, in Lynchburg carries this program at 730 P. M. Attending the luncheon and the Premiere ... from Appomattox were r Mr. and Mrs. W. M. Abbitt, Mr. and Mrs. Chas. T. document.text: Tuesday, Nov. 8, is General Election day in Virginia, and a last minute effort is being made to get out a sizeable vote for Appomattox County. There are approximately 2,500 eligible voter in the county, but thus far there has been a min imum of interest, and the size of the actual vote is uncertain. To be elected are unopposed candi dates for the State Senate and the House of Delegates, and a slate of unopposed nominees for county of fices. Polling places will open at 6 A. M. and close at 6 P. M. There are ten precincts in the county. The candidates, all Democrats, are as follows For the State Senate, Chas. T. Moses. For the House of Delegates John B. Boatwright. For Commonwealths Attorney George Abbitt, Jr. For County Treasurer John G. Plunkett. For Commissioner of the Revenue J. H. OBrien. For Sheriff David T. Robertson. For Supervisor in Southside Dis trict F. L. Murphy. For Supervisor in the Stonewall District Otho W. Martin, Jr. For Supervisor in the Colver Hill District Richard Webb. For Justice of the Peace, South- side District Cree to be elected T. W. Moses, Mrs. Lucille S. Con ner and E. T Guill. The officials to be elected Tues day will take office in January. In appealing for a good turn-out of voters next Tuesday, the quality of the candidates listed and the im portance of the eounty maintaining a record for a large vote, were cited as reasons for everyone making an effort to cast their ballots.

document.text: Thomas Butler Pretlow born in Southampton Co. 63 years ago, Mother, Ann Elizabeth Butler, of Dinwiddie Co. Father, Hon, Joshua Pretlow, of Southampton Co. Mr. Pretlows father serve in congress before and during Civil War. Mr. Pretlow served during the Spanish American War. He came to this county 16 years ago. He married Miss Annie Abbitt daughter of the late Dr. William H. Abbitt and Sarah Frances Plunkett Abbitt. Survived by wife and two children, Sarah Frances Pretlow age 12,and Joshua Pretlow age9. Relatives who attended funeral from a distance were Miss Mary Denson Pretlow and Mrs. John D. Abbitt of Norfolk, Va., Mrs. C. W. Darden of Franklin, Va., and Mrs. William Woodley of New Ben, N. C. all sisters of the deceased. Mrs. Thomas N. White, Miss Fannie Pretlow, Messrs. J. A., R. J. and Barclay Pretlow all of Franklin, Va., Mrs. G. A. Coleman, Dr. and Mrs. J. B. Abbitt and Miss Edith Abbitt, Norfolk, Va.

document.text: This highly esteemed citizen of Appomattox passed away at Staunton Hospital Saturday. Deceased served this county as sheriff for 16 years and was a popular and prominent citizen. He was born July 26, 1847 ini this county and never lived at any other place. His remains were interred at the family grave yard at his late home Sunday afternoon in the presence of a large crowd of friends and relatives. Deceased is survived by the following children Mrs. J. S. Plunkett, Mrs. T. W. Odor, H. S. and J. T. Coleman, Mrs. C. T. Cawthorn, W. p. and Miss Emma Sue Coleman, all of Ap pomattox County. Rev. W. M. Thompson con ducted the service and Senator Ferguson spoke of the service and record of deceased at the  grave. He was a confederate  soldier. .

document.text: There are great things happening in Appomattox County and you will learn about some of them if you tune in the Farm and Home Show, on WSET Channel 13, at 8 a.m. this Saturday, June 3. The show will feature Mr. Raymond Dickerson telling about the Pamplin Pipe Factory Mrs. H arriett Robin son sharing information about the Arts and Crafts Center and Mrs. Ethel Evans, Mrs. Louise Plunkett, and Mrs. Reba Bruce talking about the Patchwork Festival. Mrs. Shirley Walton and Miss Pat Hudson, Extension Agents in Appomattox County, will be hostessing the program. Dont miss it.

document.text: There are four contests awaiting the decision of the voters. In Stonewall Magisterial District there is a three-way race for the office of supervisor. Incumbent John P. Alvis, Jr., is being opposed by O. W. Martin, Jr., and Hpbert B. Scruggs. Over 800 votes are expect ed at the three precincts in Stone wall District. Veteran incumbent James H. OBrien is being opposed for nomi nation for another-term as Commis sioner of the Revenue by H. H. Caldwell, Jr. - Incumbent David T. Robertson is being opposed for Sheriff by J. Alex Bingham, a retired State Police Lieutenant. Deputy Treasurer John Garland Plunkett and Thomas Terrill Martin, are vieing for the nomination for County Treasurer. These contests have been the oc casion of active campaigns, both by the contestants and their friends. Many letters have been mailed to the voters and personal appeals have kept all hands on the go fonthe past three months. Predictions as to the outcome de pend on which side you question, but the overa-all conclusion is that there will be a heavy vote and that at least some of the contests will be close. Most contestants are preparing their workers for a major effort on1! election day and will try to see that no eligible voter fails to go to the polls. There are ten voting precincts in Appomattox County. Election offi cials, aeording to a list secured by this newspaper yesterday, will be as follows Court House Precinct Judges J. H. Lucado, L J. Mor ris and J. W. Durrum. Clerks Mrs. L. L. Stanley and Mrs. Lou C. Rog ers.

document.text: Theodore Edward Zastrow, 76. of Paoli, Ind.. died Tuesday in a Paoli hospital. He was the husband of Alma Virginia Plunkett. Zastrow. formerly of Appomattox. Born in Merrimae, Wis., he was the son of William G. Zastrow and Julia Anna Zastrow. In addition to his wife, he is survived by two daughters, Alma Zastrow and Velma Louise Zastrow of Paoli two brothers Albert Zastrow of Spout Spring and George Zastrow of Atlanta, Mich., and three sisters, Mrs. Emma Riegler and Mrs. Dorothy Johnson of Baraboo, Wis., and Mrs. Helen Rischinuller of Mer- rimac. Funeral services were held in Paoli.

About 500 participants are expected to attend. Attending from Appo mattox County are Mrs. Ethel Evans, Mrs. Margaret Lee, Mrs. Geraldine Marshall, Mrs. Louise Plunkett and Mrs. Mae Zimmerman. document.text: The Seventy-Seventh An nual Convention, Virginia Div ision of the United Daughters of the Confederacy was held in Williamsburg, Virginia, on October 3rd, and October 4th, at the Williamsburg colony Motor Inn. A Memorial Service was held in the Bruton Parish Episcopal Church honoring the deceased members of the entire Virginia Division. The total deceased members were 105, and as each name of the deceased member was called a white carnation was placed on a green wreath which was accepted by Mrs. Russell B. Frost, President of the Vir ginia Division, and was placed at the Confederate Monument in the church yard. Tuesday was Historical night and a Grand March honored the Virginia Division and General Officers. Wednesday was Chapter Presidents night, beginning with the Grand March of Presidents of all Chapters, at which time the Historians and Recorders of the Crosses of each Chapter were also recognized. The Appomattox Chapter was awarded two prizes. One, a 5.00 prize, was awarded the local Chapter for enrolling the second largest number of new members in the Virginia Div ision. The - ond, a 10.00 prize, was aw. .ed Appomat tox Chapter for giving the largest number of books to the library. Members attending from the Appomattox Chapter of the United Daughters of the con federacy were Mrs. Albert Zastrow, Chapter President Mrs. Johnnie Cyrus and her daughter, Dale Mrs. Lena Eversole, Second Vice-Presi dent Appomattox chapter Mrs. Cliff Plunkett, Virginia Divison Registrar and Mr. and Mrs. Orie Schaubach of Crewe, Virginia. 1 t-

document.text: the schedule, which is the biggest job in the beginning. Mrs. S. S. Shouse, an expert at staging flower shows, since he is an accredited flower show judge, is serving as program chairman for the show, which will be built around the Old Country Store theme. She presented a unique way of print ing the program. Mrs. W. W. Burke, and Mrs. R. C. Hubbard, co-chairman of the schedule committee, brought in a listing of items which would be of interest and typical of a Country Store. They suggested that mem bers beg or borrow such items as an Old Tobacco Plug Cutter, Old Ladies Bonnets, Home Made Lye Soap, High Top Lace Shoes, A Wooden Churn, Lamp Chimneys, etc. They would .be _used in creating the Country Store Atmosphere in staging the show. Doesnt sound much like flow ers does it? Well, just you wait and see what these ladies will do with themand the flowers. Mrs. Harwood has chosen her chairmen wisely and well in order to make this the biggest and most beautiful flower show Appomattox has ever hada show to do justice to the countys rich heritage. And it is bound  to be just that. The flo-wer show will be staged at the Old Plunkett-Meeks House at Old Appomattox Court House on April 24 and 25. Arrangements will be in keeping with the period around 1865. So whether you know it or not, all of Appomattox is going to be turned upside down in the next two months by Garden Club members rummag ing for heirlooms and other pieces of historic interest to be used in some of the rooms and in arrange ments. The ladies finally adjourned and the next visit will be to the Plunkett- Meeks House, where they will decide on placements of various types of exhibits. Here the other committees will take over, a complete listing of which will appear in a couple of weeks. You can just bet that these Garden Clubbers intend to go al out in making an outstanding event of the year in Appomattox.
